The Glimmergast

The sun was glommed, the air was chill,
And brume-whisps coiled on field and fen,
A warning crept from holt and hill,
“Eskew the Glimmergast again!”

"My swiffling son, you hear the dread?"
He took his whiffle-steel so bright,
"Its luring gleam I'll soon behead!"
And frumbled forth into the white.

He stood beside a gribble-grag,
When through the murk the Glimmergast
Came trailing like a silken rag,
With smoulder-flame and skreeking blast.

One, two! One, two! And through and through,
The whiffle-steel went *hish-thwack* deep!
Its flimmer-form it split in two,
And fell a clabbered, glowing heap.

"You've slain the Glimmergast, my star!
`Joylance! Huzzay!`" his father cried.
He bore its glinting head afar,

The sun un-glommed, the air was warming,
The brume-whisps burned from field and fen,
A brighter day was newly forming,
No Glimmergast would hunt again.
